message: RAMDisks are not cool enough for you? How about VGA RAMDisks.
story: Ahmed Al-Amir shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: Overv/vramfs
caption: github.com
description: vramfs - VRAM based file system for Linux

data.message: Finally, I can put my swap file on an encrypted file system that lives on the graphics card :P
Yeah, finally a solution to an everyday real life scenario :D

I went through its code quickly; I wouldn't use this in a real application or performance-critical ones for reasons:
- it uses one context for each GPU device. this means that multiple processes can read/write unauthorized data from/to GPU memory. a quick solution is implementing a software memory management unit (MMU), however, this would just decrease the read/write performance.
- this is a user-space library, for example: it uses the command queue in opencl and C++ to manage read/write workloads. these operations can be enhanced using kernel-space modules.
- by design, it should be slow as noted from the developer description. it is not thread safe, so it uses mutexes in reads/writes. I believe that the performance will drop in concurrent read/writes ..

For example, the tested GPU card would give you >200 GB/sec memory bandwidth, however, the achieved bandwidth is about 2 GB/sec which is 100X slower! 
When we write code that reads/writes to RAM, we expect a transfer rate of 5-10 GB/s (more or less based on the used RAM), one simply wouldn't provision for this large decrease in the transfer rate resulted from poor implementation of this library, especially with the comparison of RAM price vs GPU price. 
However, I think this is a good effort, and better implementation(s) will make it an interesting library to use or investigate. Also, it will be interesting to implement this in distributed setups.
I like it that you have been through the code, but it says right there in the intro that it is for fun and not intended for production environments :)
